Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Integrating Fossils and Molecules to Trace Ecological Divergence and Convergence in Marine Bivalves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Closely related biological species are thought to exclude one another from a particular habitat because they compete for similar food and habitat resources. Yet, many closely related species inhabit the same geographic space. This research dissects the tension between 1) the ecological pressure on closely related, co-occurring species to use different resources, and 2) the evolutionary tendency for closely related species to play similar ecological roles. By studying ecologically important traits in pairs of closely related species in the fossil record, the researchers will study the ecology of each species when it is, first, isolated from, and then co-occurs with its near relative, giving a direct window into the nature of evolutionary divergence or convergence of those species as they interact. Thus, the balance of pressures pushing species closer in form (as they enter the same environment) and pushing them apart (as they come into ecological competition) can be assessed directly. This research will collaborate with members of the ongoing Bivalve Tree of Life effort and give one of the first examples of ecological evolution over time among closely related bivalve species. Finally, this project will train one graduate student and contribute course material to the researchers? interactive Science Caf√© on the role of ecology in evolution for middle school students at the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry.

The researchers will investigate two prominent ecological hypotheses that suggest co-occurring, closely related species should differ in their ecological traits to ease direct competition for resources. ?Character displacement? predicts that competition between species after they co-occur drives their ecological divergence whereas ?species sorting? involves the co-occurrence of species that already differed ecologically before coming into sympatry. Character displacement and species sorting will be tracked in pairs of related species by using the fossil record to trace shifts from allopatry to sympatry and any corresponding change in ecological traits through time. This project will construct a molecular phylogeny for a genus of marine bivalves along the American coasts, Chione (9 extant species plus 3 extinct species fitted into the molecular tree via analysis of character matrices), which coupled with spatially explicit fossil data will provide unique access to the relation between character displacement, species sorting, and phylogenetic relatedness. Given the tendency for ecological similarity to correlate with relatedness, the researchers expect character displacement and species sorting to operate along a continuum, where character displacement predominates between more closely related species and species sorting predominates between more distantly related species. However, ecological selection imposed by the environment may trump selection mediated by competition. In that case, species will express similar ecological traits where they co-occur.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the major research areas in biology involves the relation between the ecological and the evolutionary processes that underlie the distribution of biodiversity on Earth. Does competition for resources such as food always limit the number of living organisms that can co-occur? Or, do the environmental requirements set by a particular habitat impose a more powerful limit on co-occurrence? Realistically, a combination of both biotic interactions and environmental rules likely governs the types of organisms that are found living together. The goals of this project were to dissect the relative contribution of these factors (and others, including sampling effects) to understand the current spatial pattern of biodiversity.

First, we determined that the first-order regional patterns of species richness within our model system, marine bivalves, are not likely to change with continued species discovery. This determination involved developing a statistical approach, applicable to any major biological group, based on trends in species discovery over time, broken down by region and by lineages. Given this stability in the observed record of our model system, we moved forward with analyzing a set of closely related marine bivalve species with a rich fossil record. We found that changes in bivalve shell-shape in the presence of closely related, and thus potentially competing, species correlated most closely with changes in the features of habitats. Sets of species that co-occur across habitat types all show similar shifts in shell shape, suggesting that these species largely respond to changes in environmental requirements and not to competition. We used fossil individuals from time points through fossil record of the last 5 Myr to estimate the historical breadth of shell form obtained by the clade as well as any directional evolution in shell form. We found a remarkable stability in the amount of variation in shell shape and the overall mean shell form through the history of the clade. There was minimal evidence for either ecological displacement or reoccupation of vacated ecological roles among species, suggesting a strong genetic or environmental constraint on shell shape that may in part underlie the low variation in shell form seen across degrees of co-occurrence today. 

Building on the results indicating a strong environmental control on trait expression of marine bivalves, we are expanding the phylogenetic and geographic breadth of our dataset to study the metabolic trade-offs in the construction of certain body types necessary to perform a particular ecological function and the limitations that environmental conditions may place on those body types. A first result from this effort, uncovered by an undergraduate mentored by the Co-PI Edie, indicates that a group of burrowing bivalves show correlated changes in the traits that affect burrowing efficiency. Less efficient shapes appear to be associated with internal shell features, the hinge teeth, that greater resist the shear forces involved in bivalve burrowing.

By zooming out to the larger biological scale of all marine Bivalvia, we have discovered that two components of biodiversity—the number of species or higher clades and their ecological variety—show strikingly independent behavior across modes of biodiversity loss. In three major declines in taxonomic diversity—spatially from equator to poles today and temporally in the Permian–Triassic and Cretaceous–Paleogene extinctions—only the first one shows a concomitant drop in the number of functional groups, whereas virtually all functional categories survived the two extinction events. We suggested that this contrasting pattern primarily results from the underlying gradient or persistence in resources. The diversity of food resources declines with climate across the latitudinal gradient today, drawing down both the number of species and their ecological variety. Across the two largest mass extinctions, the heavy loss of species but the persistence of ecological variety suggests greater stability of resources during these biotic upheavals than occurs from equator to poles today. Taken together, these contrasting patterns pose a key question: which pattern of diversity loss will unfold in the current biodiversity crisis, the one resembling the latitudinal diversity gradient or the mass extinctions?
